Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Collaborative Research: Towards universal signal recovery algorithms

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Ill-posed and underdetermined systems of linear equations arise in many applications ranging from healthcare to signal processing. Extensive research in the last decade has proven that ?structured? signals can be recovered ?accurately?, even if the number of observations is less than the signals? dimensions. Despite the existence of many complex structures in real-world signals, the scope of structured signal recovery has mainly remained limited to basic structures, such as sparsity and low-rankness. Extending the notion of structure and proposing efficient recovery schemes for such structured signals is one of the major open challenges in signal processing and information theory. Any progress in this direction can potentially impact many application areas such as magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).

This research involves developing a novel and transformative approach to structured signal recovery by addressing the following questions: (i) Do there exist practical and efficient signal recovery algorithms that can recover signals from their undersampled sets of linear measurements with little or no prior information about their structures? Such algorithms are referred to as universal algorithms in information theory. (ii) What are the fundamental performance limits of such universal algorithms? Universal schemes have been developed and are popular in other applications. For instance, universal compression algorithms such as the omnipresent Lempel-Ziv code achieve the optimal performance without requiring any knowledge about the distribution of the data. Recent results, by the PIs and others, theoretically prove the existence of universal signal recovery algorithms. This research investigates the existence and fundamental performance limits of computationally efficient universal recovery algorithms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ill-posed and underdetermined systems of linear equations arise in many application areas ranging from healthcare to machine learning. Extensive research in the last decade has discovered that structured signals can be recovered accurately, even if the number of observations is less than the signal dimension. These discoveries, among other technological impacts, have reduced the acquisition time of medical imaging devices, such as magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). Despite the existence of complex structures in real-world signals, the scope of this area has mainly remained limited to simple structures, such as sparsity. Finding automated methods for discovering new and complex structures in the data, and employing them in solving underdetermined systems of equations is one of the main open challenges in the area of structured signal recovery.

 To address this open challenge, we pursued the following direction in our project: Discovering universal signal recovery schemes that perform the structure discovery and signal recovery simultaneously. In the first step, we showed the existence of the universal signal recovery schemes. However, two main hurdles existed in using such schemes for practical purposes: (a) Our universal schemes required a unit that measures the complexity of any signal. (b) Finding the signal requires solving a non-convex (combinatorial) optimization problem that is in general computationally demanding. In response to the first challenge, we showed that the existing compression algorithm can be used to measure the complexity of a signal. In response to the second challenge, we developed an iterative algorithm that can efficiently find the solution of the non-convex optimization problem. Using these two ideas, we developed algorithms that achieve the state-of-the-art performance in imaging systems. Our extensive simulation studies have demonstrated the great potential of this approach in achieving a major reduction in the acquisition time of many imaging systems, such as MRI. 

Underdetermined/ill-posed systems of linear equations are widely experienced in the acquisition and analysis of many datasets, from machine learning to genomics, healthcare, and geosciences. Hence, given the generality of our approach, we expect the techniques and platforms we have developed in this project to find diverse applications in all these fields as well. Finally, we should mention the ideas we explored and developed in this project led to several other important discoveries. We list a few of them below: (i) Employing generic denoising algorithms for the structured signal recovery problem. (ii) A Bayesian approach toward the problem of structure discovery and signal recovery. (iii) Employing compression algorithms for other ill-posed problems, such as phase retrieval. Such problems arise in many application areas, such as crystallography.
